definitions.definition: the number 1

examples.text: Do you want one or two?
There's only room for one person.
One more, please!
a one-bedroomed apartment
I'll see you at one *(= one o'clock)*.

definitions.definition: used in formal language or for emphasis before hundred, thousand, etc., or before a unit of measurement

examples.text: It cost one hundred and fifty pounds.
He lost by less than one second.

definitions.definition: used for emphasis to mean ‘a single’ or ‘just one’

examples.text: There's only one thing we can do.

definitions.definition: a person or thing, especially when they are part of a group

examples.text: One of my friends lives in Brighton.
One place I'd really like to visit is Bali.

definitions.definition: used for emphasis to mean ‘the only one’ or ‘the most important one’

examples.text: He's the one person I can trust.
Her one concern was for the health of her baby.
It's the one thing I can't stand about him.

definitions.definition: used when you are talking about a time in the past or the future, without actually saying which one

examples.text: I saw her one afternoon last week.
**One day** *(= at some time in the future)* you'll understand.

definitions.definition: the same

examples.text: They all went off in one direction.

definitions.definition: used for emphasis instead of a or an

examples.text: That was one hell of a game!
She's one snappy dresser.

definitions.definition: used with a person’s name to show that the speaker does not know the person

examples.text: He worked as an assistant to one Mr Ming.

definitions.definition: in agreement; all together

examples.text: We spoke as one on this matter.

definitions.definition: to feel that you completely agree with somebody/something, or that you are part of something

examples.text: a place where you can feel at one with nature

definitions.definition: a return to the situation you were in at the beginning of a project, task, etc., because you have made no real progress

examples.text: If this suggestion isn't accepted, we'll be back to square one.

definitions.definition: to be the only person to have a particular opinion or to vote a particular way
used to emphasize that a particular person does something and that you believe other people do too

examples.text: I, for one, would prefer to postpone the meeting.

definitions.definition: to understand or guess something immediately

examples.text: ‘Oh, so she’s his sister!’ ‘Got it in one!’

definitions.definition: to get an advantage over somebody/something

examples.text: I'm not going to let them get one over on me!

definitions.definition: to do something better than somebody else or than you have done before

examples.text: She did well this year and next year she hopes to go one better.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody/something has different roles, contains different things or is used for different purposes

examples.text: She's a mother and company director in one.
It's a public relations office, a press office and a private office all in one.

definitions.definition: first one person or thing, and then another, and then another, up to any number or amount

examples.text: The bills kept coming in, one after another.

definitions.definition: everyone

examples.text: Happy New Year to one and all!

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that somebody is famous

examples.text: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

definitions.definition: used for emphasis to mean ‘the same’

examples.text: I never realized Ruth Rendell and Barbara Vine were one and the same *(= the same person using two different names)*.

definitions.definition: separately and in order

examples.text: I went through the items on the list one by one.

definitions.definition: a few

examples.text: We've had one or two problems—nothing serious.

definitions.definition: having an advantage over somebody
used to say that all types of the things mentioned are very similar

examples.text: I don't like science fiction novels much. When you've read one, you've read them all.

definitions.definition: a very long time ago

examples.text: I've been going there every summer since the year one.

wordOrigin: Old English ān, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch een and German ein, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin unus. The initial w sound developed before the 15th cent. and was occasionally represented in the spelling; it was not accepted into standard English until the late 17th cent.
